title: Public Will Pick The UK's Next Eurovision Act
text:
After another disappointing result for the UK in the Eurovision Song Contest, the public is being given an opportunity to decide which act should fly the flag next year. The BBC has been criticised in recent years for choosing an act and song to represent the country – without consulting its many millions of devoted Eurovision fans.
This year's band, Electro Velvet, failed to finish in the top 20 acts of 2015 – but even the likes of Bonnie Tyler and Engelbert Humperdinck have struggled to dazzle the continent.
It is hoped the X Factor-style talent search, spearheaded by Atomic Kitten and a former record boss, will unearth an up and coming act who is music to Europe's ears.
Anyone who is aged 18 or over can submit a video of them performing an original track, and the chosen performer will represent the UK at the next contest in May 2016.
1 / 19 Gallery: Sweden Victorious At Song Competition In Vienna
Sweden's Mans Zelmerlow took the crown with his performance of Heroes
Graham Norton, who lends his pithy commentary to the competition, said: "Eurovision is one of the highlights of my year.
"The fact that the public gets the final say on who is sent to represent the UK in Stockholm next year is the icing on the cake."
The UK last won the Eurovision Song Contest in 1997, when Katrina And The Waves performed Love Shine A Light.
1 / 10 Gallery: 2014: Millions Tune In
Singers from 26 countries took part in the 59th annual Eurovision Song Contest in Copenhagen. An estimated global audience of 180 million was expected to tune in to watch the spectacle.
Unfortunately, a dreaded "nul points" was more recent – with Jemini gaining the dubious honour of coming home with a score of zero back in 2003.
